childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1997-2009

The year 1997 brought Princess Diana's Mercedes hitting a concrete pillar in the Pont de l'Alma tunnel, turning a princess into a mythology and introducing this generation to the concept of celebrity death as global trauma. While newborns were learning to focus their eyes, a billion people watched her funeral on television, the flowers outside Kensington Palace piled high enough to smell from space.

Dolly the sheep proved cloning wasn't just science fiction anymore. The first Harry Potter book appeared in British bookshops, destined to become this generation's personality test and sorting hat obsession. Hong Kong went back to China after 156 years of British rule. Tony Blair swept into 10 Downing Street with that grin and those promises. The Spice Girls conquered the planet with platform shoes and girl power.

Earliest memories for this cohort probably smell like those plastic Fisher-Price toys and feel like the textured carpet of a living room where adults watched news that made them anxious. This cohort was four years old when hijacked planes flew into the World Trade Center, too young to understand but old enough to sense that something fundamental had cracked. The adults around them got scared in ways they tried to hide. Security checkpoints became normal. The phrase 'War on Terror' entered the vocabulary they'd inherit.

This cohort learned to read while America invaded Iraq. They started elementary school in a country that had decided perpetual war was just how things worked now. Childhood included lockdown drills alongside fire drills, active shooter protocols explained in the same calm voice as tornado procedures. They never knew schools any other way.

Elementary school years coincided with the late 2000s recession. This cohort was old enough to notice when parents' conversations got tense and quiet, when the word 'layoff' entered household discussions. They absorbed the anxiety without fully understanding the mechanisms—just that something had shifted in the stability they'd assumed was permanent.

generational_identity.html:
The Gen Z Generation

Gen Z, born between 1997 and 2012. Those born in 1997 are the eldest of Generation Z, the cohort researchers defined by what they don't remember: a pre-digital world, a pre-9/11 America, a time when phones were attached to walls and getting lost was still possible. Pew Research drew the line at 1997 because this is the generation too young to remember 9/11 consciously but old enough to be shaped entirely by its aftermath.

Gen Z numbers roughly 68 million Americans, the most racially diverse generation in the nation's history. Nearly half identify as non-white. This generation grew up in classrooms where the concept of a racial majority was already becoming meaningless in many ZIP codes. Same-sex marriage became legal when this cohort was eighteen, which means marriage equality has always been part of their adult understanding of the world. Gen Z didn't adopt social media—they were raised by it, shaped by it, formed in its image.

Being the oldest Gen Z means this cohort serves as translators between worlds. They remember dial-up modems making that unholy screech. They remember when getting online was an event, not a state of being. They remember car trips without GPS, boredom without YouTube, socializing without Instagram. This gives them something their younger generational siblings lack: the ability to imagine life without constant connectivity, even if they can barely remember living it.

The stereotypes paint Gen Z as anxious, phone-addicted, attention-span-deficient snowflakes who can't handle adversity. The reality is messier. Gen Z is pragmatic because optimism keeps getting punished. They're anxious because climate change is real and nobody in power is fixing it. They're digitally fluent because that's where life happens now. They're not fragile—they're exhausted from caring about too many existential threats simultaneously. Gen Z has never expected stability because they've never experienced it.

Gen Z communicates in memes, processes trauma through humor, and has a relationship with irony so deep that sincerity requires warning labels. This generation is simultaneously the most connected humans in history and the loneliest according to every metric researchers track. That paradox isn't a bug in Gen Z—it's the defining feature.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The year 1997 brought Titanic, which made Leonardo DiCaprio the most famous human on Earth and convinced an entire generation that freezing to death was romantic if the string section was good enough. James Cameron's ship sank for three hours and twelve minutes while grossing $2.2 billion, proving that disaster sells when wrapped in a love story. Kate Winslet made every teenage girl want to be drawn like a French girl, whatever that meant.

The Spice Girls released 'Wannabe' the year before this cohort was born, and by their first birthday they dominated everything. Girl power in platform shoes, manufactured authenticity, the template for every pop group that would follow. Meanwhile, Radiohead's 'OK Computer' predicted the digital alienation this cohort would grow up experiencing: 'Fitter, happier, more productive' as prophecy, not satire.

Men in Black established Will Smith as the coolest action star of the decade. Good Will Hunting introduced Matt Damon solving equations on a chalkboard and made everyone briefly believe janitors might be secret geniuses. The Full Monty proved British unemployment could be funny with added choreography.

Childhood belonged to Harry Potter, which wasn't just a book series but a personality sorting system, a shared language, a reason to check mailboxes for letters that never came. This cohort grew up alongside those characters, aging roughly in sync with them, waiting for midnight book releases and movie premieres. SpongeBob SquarePants premiered when this cohort was two and became the background radiation of their childhood, its absurdist humor training this generation's comedy instincts.

By middle school, this cohort had witnessed the birth of YouTube, the rise and fall of Vine, the emergence of whatever platform was dominating that particular semester. Content replaced media. Virality replaced quality. The monoculture fragmented into algorithm-driven niches, and this generation became the first to grow up without shared cultural touchstones beyond memes that lasted a week.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

The year 1997 saw Deep Blue defeat Garry Kasparov at chess, the first time a machine beat a human world champion at something that mattered. It was a preview of the AI anxiety this generation would eventually inherit, a glimpse of silicon thinking faster than neurons. Also in 1997: a Stanford PhD project registered the domain google.com. The company that would organize all human knowledge, then monetize the organizing, was just getting started.

The dot-com boom was inflating when this cohort was born; it burst spectacularly when they were three. Sock puppet mascots and 'eyeballs before profits' startups imploded. The NASDAQ crashed 78% from peak to trough. This cohort doesn't remember it, but their parents might have lost money, jobs, or faith in technology as a path to guaranteed prosperity.

The technology timeline for this cohort moves in iPhone increments. They were ten when Steve Jobs unveiled that glass rectangle in 2007, changing everything about how humans interact with information and each other. They probably got their first smartphone around middle school—maybe a hand-me-down iPhone, maybe an Android, maybe one of those transitional devices that wasn't quite smart but wasn't dumb either.

Social media arrived in stages that tracked this cohort's development. Facebook launched when they were seven, but it was for college students then. By the time they were old enough to want an account, it was already for parents. Instagram appeared when they were thirteen, Snapchat when they were fourteen, TikTok (as Musical.ly) when they were seventeen. Each platform arrived just as they aged into its target demographic.

This cohort is the first generation that can't remember a time before the internet was everywhere, but they're also the last generation that remembers when it wasn't in their pocket. That slight generational delay—getting smartphones at ten instead of five—might matter. They had a few years of boredom, of being unreachable, of looking out car windows without a screen as alternative. Whether that inoculated them against anything or just made the eventual addiction hit harder is still being debated.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

Princess Diana died four months after this cohort was born, her Mercedes crumpled against concrete in a Paris tunnel while paparazzi flashbulbs created the final images. A billion people watched the funeral. It was the first media event of the 24-hour news cycle era, the template for collective grief in the internet age, the moment when celebrity death became participatory sport.

This cohort was four years old on September 11, 2001. Too young to remember the towers falling, old enough to sense the fear radiating from every adult. Their parents were glued to televisions showing footage that would replay for years. The world they'd grow up in was being forged in that fire and smoke. They'd never know airports without security theater, never experience a pre-surveillance America, never understand why older people seemed nostalgic for a country they'd never lived in.

Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans when this cohort was eight, bodies floating on television, people stranded on rooftops waving at helicopters that didn't stop, a president who seemed confused about why people were drowning. It was this generation's first glimpse of how government fails when the victims are poor and Black.

At {{AGE_AT_IPHONE}}, the iPhone changed everything about how humans interact with information. The 2008 financial crisis hit when this cohort was eleven, old enough to understand that something bad was happening even if the mechanics were opaque. Their parents' retirement accounts evaporated. Neighbors lost houses. The recovery was slow and uneven and reshaped the economic landscape they'd enter as a young adult.

Sandy Hook happened when this cohort was fifteen. Twenty first-graders murdered in their classroom, and nothing changed. If Columbine taught older generations that schools could be dangerous, Sandy Hook taught this one that adults would offer thoughts and prayers and do nothing else. This cohort organized after Parkland because they'd internalized that no one was coming to save them.

At {{AGE_AT_COVID}}, COVID-19 hit. This cohort was twenty during the pandemic, twenty-one during the January 6th insurrection, twenty-three when they watched democracy and competence compete in real time. Early adulthood has been a series of 'unprecedented' events, each one less surprising than the last, all of them teaching the same lesson: stability is a story previous generations told themselves.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

This cohort entered the workforce around 2019-2020, which means COVID probably detonated whatever career trajectory they'd imagined. Internships evaporated. Entry-level positions vanished into hiring freezes. Remote onboarding meant learning office culture through a screen while cats walked across keyboards during video calls. First professional experiences happened in a crisis mode that never quite ended.

The job market Gen Z entered doesn't reward employer loyalty because this generation has never witnessed it. Their parents got laid off in 2008 or 2001 or whenever the economy decided to shed jobs. This cohort watched them scramble, rebuild, learn that decades of service meant nothing when quarterly numbers disappointed shareholders. The implicit contract—work hard and workers will be taken care of—was broken before they could believe in it.

Side hustles aren't optional for Gen Z; they're risk mitigation. This generation sells things on Depop, drives for DoorDash, monetizes TikTok, freelances on Fiverr, or does whatever combination of gig work keeps the math from breaking. Depending on a single income source seems naive when they've seen how fast 'stable' employment becomes unemployment.

Gen Z negotiates differently than previous generations. Salary transparency isn't taboo for them—it's strategy. They share compensation data openly, knowing that secrecy only benefits employers. They ask about work-life balance in interviews because they've seen what happens to people who give everything to companies that would replace them in a heartbeat. They want the job, but they want a life too.

Remote work is Gen Z's default assumption. They've never romanticized the commute or believed that productivity requires a cubicle. They're suspicious of return-to-office mandates that can't articulate why physical presence matters. The ping-pong table in the break room doesn't impress them. Fair wages and boundaries do.

Gen Z is entering a job market where AI can do significant portions of entry-level work. The skills they learned in college are already being automated. The jobs they'll have at forty probably don't exist yet. Adaptation isn't a nice-to-have—it's the entire job description.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Gen Z has been dating-app-native since they started dating. Tinder launched when this cohort was sixteen. Bumble when they were eighteen. By the time they were old enough to seriously pursue relationships, swiping was the default interface. The idea of approaching a stranger in public and asking for their number feels like advice from a period drama—theoretically possible, socially unthinkable.

Gen Z invented the 'talking stage,' that liminal space between matching and officially dating that can stretch for weeks or months. They're experts at maintaining ambiguity, partly because commitment feels risky in a world where nothing else is stable, partly because they've watched too many relationships play out publicly online and learned that investing too visibly invites humiliation.

Gen Z communicates through layers of mediation. DMs for real conversation, Stories for curated updates, BeReals for performed authenticity, Snaps for ephemeral intimacy. Each platform has different rules, different audiences, different versions of themselves. Managing these digital identities is exhausting, but they've been doing it so long they don't know how to stop.

Gen Z is having less sex than previous generations at the same age, which confuses older people and concerns researchers. The reasons are complicated: phones in bedrooms, dating app fatigue, economic stress making partnership seem impossible, mental health struggles that sap desire. Whatever the causes, physical intimacy is happening less often and later in life.

Friendship for Gen Z often exists primarily in group chats and Discord servers. Their closest friends might live across the country. Physical proximity matters less than digital presence. This felt isolating during COVID, when online was the only option, but it also meant they were more prepared for distributed connection than any generation before.

Gen Z has normalized discussing mental health, boundaries, and attachment styles in ways that would mystify their grandparents. Therapy-speak is their native language. Whether this makes relationships healthier or just more self-conscious depends on who's asking. What's undeniable is that they talk about emotional dynamics with a vocabulary previous generations lacked.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

This cohort was {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}} during the 2008 crash. They watched their parents' retirement accounts evaporate, their job security vanish, their confidence in institutions crater. They absorbed the lesson before they had a bank account: economic stability is a shared hallucination that can shatter overnight when enough people stop believing. Gen Z has never believed in economic stability because they've never seen it last.

This cohort entered adulthood during COVID, another economic implosion with a different face. Two massive financial crises before age twenty-five shaped their worldview: less 'plan for the future' and more 'survive the present while hoping the future exists.'

Student debt defines Gen Z's economic reality the way mortgages defined their parents'. The average graduate in this cohort owes around $30,000, sometimes much more. The jobs available don't pay enough to service that debt and also pay rent, buy food, and have something resembling a life. The math doesn't work.

The housing market is challenging. Prices have climbed vertically while wages flatlined horizontally. The down payment they'd need is more than they make in a year. They're competing with cash offers from investors and boomers downsizing from even bigger houses. Renting forever isn't a lifestyle choice—it's the only option that doesn't require winning a lottery or inheriting wealth.

Gen Z invests differently because traditional investing assumes stability they've never experienced. They're into crypto, meme stocks, fractional shares bought through apps with gamified interfaces. The advice their parents got—max out a 401(k), buy index funds, wait forty years—assumes a world that will exist in forty years and will reward patience. They're less certain about both.

Gen Z spends on experiences rather than things because experiences are achievable and things are not. Concerts, travel, meals out. If they can't have the house, at least they can have the memory. They're not irresponsible. They're rational actors responding to irrational conditions.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

Gen Z's biggest weakness is conflating awareness with action. They know about every problem—climate change, inequality, systemic racism, mental health crises—because the information is constant and inescapable. But knowing about problems isn't the same as solving them. Sometimes the constant awareness creates paralysis. They're so overwhelmed by everything that needs fixing that they fix nothing, substituting outrage for effort.

Gen Z is so accustomed to performing authenticity online that they've lost track of what authenticity actually feels like. Every emotional moment is potentially content. Every opinion is potentially engagement. The line between genuine experience and shareable experience has blurred to the point where they're not sure which version of themselves is real and which is the curated avatar.

Gen Z's irony is a defense mechanism that sometimes prevents genuine connection. Everything is a joke, a reference, a meme. Earnestness feels cringe. But some things—love, grief, hope, conviction—don't survive being ironized. By refusing to be sincere, they rob themselves of experiences that require sincerity to feel real.

Gen Z has been told they're special their entire life, which creates both entitlement and crushing disappointment when the world fails to recognize their specialness. The gap between expected success and actual opportunities creates a specific despair that's hard to articulate without sounding ungrateful.

Gen Z's relationship with attention is fundamentally broken. They've been trained to seek validation through likes, follows, and engagement metrics. The dopamine hit of social media approval has rewired how they experience achievement. Accomplishments that don't translate to content feel somehow less real. They're performing their life for an audience that doesn't actually care.

Gen Z is so good at advocating for mental health that they sometimes pathologize normal human emotions. Not every bad day is depression. Not every preference is a trauma response. The therapeutic language that helps them understand themselves can also become a way of avoiding the full range of human messiness by giving everything a clinical label.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

The 20s (2017-2027): This cohort is in this decade now. They graduated into economic uncertainty, came of age during a pandemic, and entered adulthood in a world that seems to be actively falling apart. This is supposed to be their exploration decade, but economic pressure makes exploration feel like a luxury only people with rich parents can afford. They're building skills, accumulating experiences, trying to figure out what matters while also trying to pay rent. They're exhausted in ways that feel premature. Twenty-seven shouldn't feel this tired.

The 30s (2027-2037): This is when things supposedly stabilize—marriage, kids, career advancement, maybe finally buying a home. Whether that's possible depends on factors outside their control: the economy, climate policy, political stability, whether the systems holding society together continue holding. They'll have more clarity about what they want. Whether they can get it is a different question. Their parents will be aging. They might become responsible for their care while still trying to establish their own life.

The 40s (2037-2047): Peak earning years, statistically. They'll probably be managing people, making decisions, wielding whatever authority their career has granted. Climate change will have reshaped geography and migration patterns. AI will have transformed work in ways we can barely predict. The skills they learned in their twenties will be obsolete, replaced by skills they'll have to acquire mid-career. Their kids, if they have them, will be teenagers dealing with problems that haven't been invented yet.

The 50s (2047-2057): They'll be pre-retirement age, but 'retirement' might be a meaningless concept by then. Social Security's future is uncertain. The economy will have gone through several more cycles of boom and bust. They'll be the older generation, explaining to young people what life was like before smartphones were in everyone's pocket, before AI was everywhere, before the climate got really weird. They won't believe them.

The 60s and beyond (2057+): The world of 2060 is unimaginable from here. Every projection is science fiction. What's certain: they'll be among the last people who remember life before constant connectivity, before algorithmic everything, before whatever comes next. That perspective will be valuable or quaint depending on what kind of world emerges. Whatever happens, they'll have navigated more disruption than any generation in recent memory. That resilience has to count for something.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

This cohort is part of roughly {{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people born in {{BIRTH_YEAR}}. Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), Gen Z is similar but more pessimistic. Millennials had a brief window of optimism before 2008 crushed it. Gen Z never had that window. Millennials believed institutions could be reformed; Gen Z watched those reform efforts fail. Millennials remember life before the internet took over; Gen Z doesn't. Millennials are angry about what was taken from them. Gen Z can't miss what they never had.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), Gen Z is practically from different planets. Gen X grew up analog and adapted to digital. Gen Z grew up digital and are watching AI change everything again. Gen X had affordable college and houses that cost less than Gen Z's student loans. Gen X got stable jobs when stable jobs existed. Gen X's cynicism was an aesthetic choice; Gen Z's is survival strategy.

Gen X controlled 21% of national wealth at this age; Gen Z controls roughly 5%. Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), the wealth gap is significant. Boomers inherited the post-war economic boom, affordable education, growing wages, pensions that actually paid out. They bought houses on single incomes. They accumulated wealth when assets were cheap. They keep asking why Gen Z can't afford a house. The answer is that they pulled up the ladder.

Compared to Gen Alpha (born 2013-2025), Gen Z is the older, slightly more grounded version. Gen Alpha is growing up entirely post-smartphone, post-pandemic, post-whatever stability existed before 2020. Gen Z at least remembers a time before things got this weird. Gen Alpha won't have that anchor. Gen Z can still function when the Wi-Fi goes out. Gen Alpha might not be able to.

Gen Z's mental health statistics are concerning. This generation reports higher rates of anxiety and depression than any previous generation at the same age. Whether this is because they're actually more distressed or because they're more willing to discuss it openly is debated. Probably both. Gen Z is the most connected generation in history and also the loneliest. What's undeniable is that they're the most medicated, most therapized generation in history. Life expectancy for this cohort is projected around 78-80 years, though mental health outcomes create uncertainty. Whether that's enough to offset the structural disadvantages they've inherited remains to be seen.

year_events: Princess Diana died in Paris tunnel crash
Hong Kong returned to Chinese sovereignty
Titanic became highest-grossing film in history
Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone published
Deep Blue defeated Garry Kasparov at chess
Tony Blair became UK Prime Minister
Dolly the sheep proved cloning was possible
